query: site:github.com titanic GROUNDTRUTH.csv test set survival labels

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: There is no publicly available GROUNDTRUTH.csv containing the test‑set survival labels; the test set is provided without ground‑truth outcomes, only the training set includes the “ground truth” column. ([github.com](https://github.com/harbidel/TITANIC))

results.title: GitHub - harbidel/TITANIC: The historical data has been split into two groups, a 'training set' and a 'test set'. For the training set, we provide the outcome ( 'ground truth' ) for each passenger. You will use this set to build your model to generate predictions for the test set.  For each passenger in the test set, you must predict whether or not they survived the sinking ( 0 for deceased, 1 for survived ). Your score is the percentage of passengers you correctly predict.  The leaderboard has a public and private component. 50% of your predictions for the test set have been randomly assigned to the public leaderboard ( the same 50% for all users ). Your score on this public portion is what will appear on the leaderboard. At the end of the contest, we will reveal your score on the private 50% of the data, which will determine the final winner. This method prevents users from 'overfitting' to the leaderboard.  Data Description  Overview The data has been split into two groups: training set (train.csv) test set (test.csv)  The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features.  The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic.  Data Dictionary Variable Definition Key  survival Survival 0 = No, 1 = Yes  pclass Ticket class 1 = 1st, 2 = 2nd, 3 = 3rd  sex Sex  Age Age in years  sibsp # of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic

results.title: GitHub - prason3106/THE-TITANIC-PROBLEM: You will have 2 datasets. One dataset is titled train.csv and the other is titled test.csv.  Train.csv will contain the details of a subset of the passengers on board (891 to be exact) and importantly, will reveal whether they survived or not, also known as the “ground truth”.  The test.csv dataset contains similar information but does not disclose the “ground truth” for each passenger. It’s your job to predict these outcomes.  Using the patterns you find in the train.csv data, predict whether the other 418 passengers on board (found in test.csv) survived.  This Notebook will show basic examples of: Data Handling Importing Data with Pandas Cleaning Data Exploring Data through Visualizations with Matplotlib  Data Analysis Supervised Machine learning Techniques: Logit Regression Model Plotting results Support Vector Machine (SVM) using 3 kernels Basic Random Forest Plotting results  Valuation of the Analysis K-folds cross validation to valuate results locally Output the results from the IPython Notebook to csv file  Required Libraries: NumPy IPython Pandas SciKit-Learn SciPy StatsModels Patsy Matplotlib

One dataset is titled train.csv and the other is titled test.csv. Train.csv will contain the details of a subset of the passengers on board (891 to be exact) and importantly, will reveal whether they survived or not, also known as the “ground truth”. The test.csv dataset contains similar information but does not disclose the “ground truth” for each passenger. It’s your job to predict these outcomes. Using the patterns you find in the train.csv data, predict whether the other 418 passengers on board (found in test.csv) survived. This Notebook will show basic examples of: Data Handling Importing Data with Pandas Cleaning Data Exploring Data through Visualizations with Matplotlib Data Analysis Supervised Machine learning Techniques: Logit Regression Model Plotting results Support Vector Machine (SVM) using 3 kernels Basic Random Forest Plotting results Valuation of the Analysis K-folds cross validation to valuate results locally Output the results from the IPython Notebook to csv file Required Libraries: NumPy IPython Pandas SciKit-Learn SciPy StatsModels Patsy Matplotlib ## About You will have 2 datasets. One dataset is titled train.csv and the other is titled test.csv. Train.csv will contain the details of a subset of the passengers on board (891 to be exact) and importantly, will reveal whether they survived or not, also known as the “ground truth”. ## History
[3 Commits](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/commits/main/) | | [README.md](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/README.md) | [README.md](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/README.md) | | | | [Titanic\_Disaster\_DataAnalysis.ipynb](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/Titanic_Disaster_DataAnalysis.ipynb) | [Titanic\_Disaster\_DataAnalysis.ipynb](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/Titanic_Disaster_DataAnalysis.ipynb) | | | | [test.csv](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/test.csv) | [test.csv](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/test.csv) | | | | [train.csv](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/train.csv) | [train.csv](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/blob/main/train.csv) | | | | View all files | ## Repository files navigation # Titanic--Survival-Prediction (Kaggle) This is the legendary Titanic ML competition – the best, first challenge for you to dive into ML competitions and familiarize yourself with how the Kaggle platform works. The competition is simple: use machine learning to create a model that predicts which passengers survived the Titanic shipwreck. The sinking of the Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history. On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the widely considered “unsinkable” RMS Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg. Unfortunately, there weren’t enough lifeboats for everyone onboard, resulting in the death of 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew. While there was some element of luck involved in surviving, it seems some groups of people were more likely to survive than others. In this challenge, we ask you to build a predictive model that answers the question: “what sorts of people were more likely to survive?” using passenger data (ie name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc). The data has been split into two groups: training set (train.csv) test set (test.csv) The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features. The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic.\ Variable Notes: pclass: A proxy for socio-economic status (SES) 1st = Upper 2nd = Middle 3rd = Lower age: Age is fractional if less than 1. If the age is estimated, is it in the form of xx.5 sibsp: The dataset defines family relations in this way... Sibling = brother, sister, stepbrother, stepsister Spouse = husband, wife (mistresses and fiancés were ignored) parch: The dataset defines family relations in this way... Parent = mother, father Child = daughter, son, stepdaughter, stepson Some children travelled only with a nanny, therefore parch=0 for them. ## About No description, website, or topics provided. ### Resources [Readme](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-#readme-ov-file) [Activity](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/activity) ### Stars [**1**\ star](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/stargazers) ### Watchers [**1**\ watching](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/watchers) ### Forks [**0**\ forks](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/forks) [Report repository](https://github.com/contact/report-content?content_url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FMohnish4533%2FTitanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-&report=Mohnish4533+%28user%29) ## [Releases](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/releases) No releases published ## [Packages\ 0](https://github.com/users/Mohnish4533/packages?repo_name=Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-) No packages published ## Languages - [Jupyter Notebook100.0%](https://github.com/Mohnish4533/Titanic---Survival-Prediction-kaggle-/search?l=jupyter-notebook) You can’t perform that action at this time.

For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features. The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic. ## About Passenger survival in the Titanic shipwreck ### Resources [Readme](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic#readme-ov-file) [Activity](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/activity) ### Stars [**1**\ star](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/stargazers) ### Watchers [**1**\ watching](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/watchers) ### Forks [**0**\ forks](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/forks) [Report repository](https://github.com/contact/report-content?content_url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Faditya-magdum%2FTitanic&report=aditya-magdum+%28user%29) ## [Releases](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/releases) No releases published ## [Packages\ 0](https://github.com/users/aditya-magdum/packages?repo_name=Titanic) No packages published ## Languages - [Jupyter Notebook100.0%](https://github.com/aditya-magdum/Titanic/search?l=jupyter-notebook) You can’t perform that action at this time.

## History
[3 Commits](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/commits/main/) | | ### [README.md](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/README.md) | ### [README.md](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/README.md) | | | | ### [gender\_submission.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/gender_submission.csv) | ### [gender\_submission.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/gender_submission.csv) | | | | ### [test.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/test.csv) | ### [test.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/test.csv) | | | | ### [titanic\_project.ipynb](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/titanic_project.ipynb) | ### [titanic\_project.ipynb](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/titanic_project.ipynb) | | | | ### [train.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/train.csv) | ### [train.csv](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/blob/main/train.csv) | | | | View all files | ## Repository files navigation # Titanic-Survuval-Prediction Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history. On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg, killing 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew. This sensational tragedy shocked the international community and led to better safety regulations for ships. What particularly we need do in this challange ? In this challenge, we need to complete the analysis of what sorts of people were likely to survive. In particular, we apply the tools of machine learning to predict which passengers survived the tragedy. Overview The data has been split into two groups: • training set (train.csv) • test set (test.csv) The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features. The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic. We also include gender\_submission.csv, a set of predictions that assume all and only female passengers survive, as an example of what a submission file should look like. What does this data set mean? The data has been split into two groups: • training set (train.csv) • test set(test.csv) The training set includes passengers survival status(also know as the ground truth from the titanic tragedy) which along with other features like gender, class, fare and pclass is used to create machine learning model. The test set should be used to see how well my model performs on unseen data. The test set does not provide passengers survival status. We are going to use our model to predict passenger survival status. Lets describe whats the meaning of the features given the both train & test datasets. Variable Definition Key. • Survival • 0= No • 1= Yes • pclass (Ticket class) • 1=1st • 2=2nd • 3=3rd • sex • age • sibsp (# of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic) • parch (# of parents / children aboard the Titanic) • tickets • fare • cabin • embarked Port of Embarkation. • C = Cherbourg, • Q = Queenstown, • S = Southampton • pclass: A proxy for socio-economic status (SES) • This is important to remember and will come in handy for later analysis. • 1st = Upper • 2nd = Middle • 3rd = Lower ## About No description, website, or topics provided. ### Resources [Readme](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction#readme-ov-file) [Activity](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/activity) ### Stars [**1**\ star](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/stargazers) ### Watchers [**1**\ watching](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/watchers) ### Forks [**0**\ forks](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/forks) [Report repository](https://github.com/contact/report-content?content_url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fabhiee1898%2FTitanic-Survival-Prediction&report=abhiee1898+%28user%29) ## [Releases](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/releases) No releases published ## [Packages\ 0](https://github.com/users/abhiee1898/packages?repo_name=Titanic-Survival-Prediction) No packages published ## Languages - [Jupyter Notebook100.0%](https://github.com/abhiee1898/Titanic-Survival-Prediction/search?l=jupyter-notebook) You can’t perform that action at this time.

# Kaggle-Competition-Titanic-Analysis\_Repository
[](#kaggle-competition-titanic-analysis_repository)
Referenced:[https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic/overview](https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic/overview)
Overview:
'''
This is the legendary Titanic ML competition –the best, first challenge for you to dive into ML competitions and familiarize yourself with how the Kaggle platform works.
The competition is simple: use machine learning to create a model that predicts which passengers survived the Titanic shipwreck.
Read on or watch the video below to explore more details. Once you’re ready to start competing, click on the "Join Competition button to create an account and gain access to the competition data. Then check out Alexis Cook’s Titanic Tutorial that walks you through step by step how to make your first submission!
The Challenge
The sinking of the Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history.
On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the widely considered “unsinkable” RMS Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg. Unfortunately, there weren’t enough lifeboats for everyone onboard, resulting in the death of 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew.
While there was some element of luck involved in surviving, it seems some groups of people were more likely to survive than others.
In this challenge, we ask you to build a predictive model that answers the question: “what sorts of people were more likely to survive?” using passenger data (ie name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc).
Recommended Tutorial
We highly recommend Alexis Cook’s Titanic Tutorial that walks you through making your very first submission step by step.
Overview of How Kaggle’s Competitions Work
1. Join the Competition
Read about the challenge description, accept the Competition Rules and gain access to the competition dataset.
1. Get to Work
Download the data, build models on it locally or on Kaggle Kernels (our no-setup, customizable Jupyter Notebooks environment with free GPUs) and generate a prediction file.
1. Make a Submission
Upload your prediction as a submission on Kaggle and receive an accuracy score.
1. Check the Leaderboard
See how your model ranks against other Kagglers on our leaderboard.
1. Improve Your Score
Check out the discussion forum to find lots of tutorials and insights from other competitors.
Kaggle Lingo Video
You may run into unfamiliar lingo as you dig into the Kaggle discussion forums and public notebooks. Check out Dr. Rachael Tatman’s video on Kaggle Lingo to get up to speed!
What Data Will I Use in This Competition?
In this competition, you’ll gain access to two similar datasets that include passenger information like name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc. One dataset is titled`train.csv`and the other is titled`test.csv`.
Train.csv will contain the details of a subset of the passengers on board (891 to be exact) and importantl...

[3 Commits](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/commits/main/) | | [Dockerfile](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/Dockerfile) | [Dockerfile](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/Dockerfile) | | [README.md](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/README.md) | [README.md](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/README.md) | | [eval.py](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/eval.py) | [eval.py](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/eval.py) | | [ground\_truth.csv](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/ground_truth.csv) | [ground\_truth.csv](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/ground_truth.csv) | | [pipeline.py](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/pipeline.py) | [pipeline.py](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/pipeline.py) | | [pipeline.zip](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/pipeline.zip) | [pipeline.zip](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/blob/main/pipeline.zip) | | View all files | ## Repository files navigation # titanic This is the legendary Titanic ML competition – the best, first challenge for you to dive into ML competitions and familiarize yourself with how the Kaggle platform works. The competition is simple: use machine learning to create a model that predicts which passengers survived the Titanic shipwreck. Read on or watch the video below to explore more details. [How to Get Started with Titanic Competition](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8yZMXCaFshs&feature=youtu.be) # The Challenge The sinking of the Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history. On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the widely considered “unsinkable” RMS Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg. Unfortunately, there weren’t enough lifeboats for everyone onboard, resulting in the death of 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew. While there was some element of luck involved in surviving, it seems some groups of people were more likely to survive than others. In this challenge, we ask you to build a predictive model that answers the question: “what sorts of people were more likely to survive?” using passenger data (ie name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc). # Data The data has been split into two groups: training set ( [train.csv](https://dkube.s3.amazonaws.com/datasets/titanic/train.csv)) test set ( [test.csv](https://dkube.s3.amazonaws.com/datasets/titanic/test.csv)) The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features. The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic. We also include gender\_submission.csv, a set of predictions that assume all and only female passengers survive, as an example of what a submission file should look like. | Variable | Definition | Key | | --- | --- | --- | | survival | Survival | 0 = No, 1 = Yes | | pclass | Ticket class | 1 = 1st, 2 = 2nd, 3 = 3rd | | sex | Sex | | Age | Age in years | | sibsp | \# of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic | | parch | \# of parents / children aboard the Titanic | | ticket | Ticket number | | fare | Passenger fare | | cabin | Cabin number | | embarked | Port of Embarkation | C = Cherbourg, Q = Queenstown, S = Southampton | # Variable Notes pclass: A proxy for socio-economic status (SES) 1st = Upper 2nd = Middle 3rd = Lower age: Age is fractional if less than 1. If the age is estimated, is it in the form of xx.5 sibsp: The dataset defines family relations in this way... Sibling = brother, sister, stepbrother, stepsister Spouse = husband, wife (mistresses and fiancés were ignored) parch: The dataset defines family relations in this way... Parent = mother, father Child = daughter, son, stepdaughter, stepson Some children travelled only with a nanny, therefore parch=0 for them. ## About Titanic example from Kaggle : Project owner repo ### Resources [Readme](https://github.com/github.com#readme-ov-file) ### Uh oh! There was an error while loading. Please reload this page. [Activity](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/activity) [Custom properties](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/custom-properties) ### Stars [**0**\ stars](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/stargazers) ### Watchers [**11**\ watching](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/watchers) ### Forks [**1**\ fork](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/forks) [Report repository](https://github.com/contact/report-content?content_url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Foneconvergence%2Ftitanic-owner&report=oneconvergence+%28user%29) ## [Releases](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/releases) No releases published ## [Packages\ 0](https://github.com/orgs/oneconvergence/packages?repo_name=titanic-owner) No packages published ## Languages - [Python93.5%](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/search?l=python) - [Dockerfile6.5%](https://github.com/oneconvergence/titanic-owner/search?l=dockerfile) You can’t perform that action at this time.

[9 Commits](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/commits/main/) | | [README.md](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/README.md) | [README.md](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/README.md) | | [test.csv](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/test.csv) | [test.csv](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/test.csv) | | [titanic-challenge (8).ipynb](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/titanic-challenge%20(8).ipynb) | [titanic-challenge (8).ipynb](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/titanic-challenge%20(8).ipynb) | | [train.csv](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/train.csv) | [train.csv](https://github.com/Amanda-Amaral/TitanicKaggle/blob/main/train.csv) | | View all files | ## Repository files navigation # Titanic Kaggle Challenge ## The Challenge #### The sinking of the Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history. #### On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the widely considered “unsinkable” RMS Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg. Unfortunately, there weren’t enough lifeboats \#\#\#\#for everyone onboard, resulting in the death of 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew. #### While there was some element of luck involved in surviving, it seems some groups of people were more likely to survive than others. ### In this challenge, we ask you to build a predictive model that answers the question: “what sorts of people were more likely to survive?” using passenger data (ie name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc). ## What Data Will I Use in This Competition? #### In this competition, you’ll gain access to two similar datasets that include passenger information like name, age, gender, socio-economic class, etc. One dataset is titled `train.csv` and the other is titled `test.csv`. #### Train.csv will contain the details of a subset of the passengers on board (891 to be exact) and importantly, will reveal whether they survived or not, also known as the “ground truth”. #### The `test.csv` dataset contains similar information but does not disclose the “ground truth” for each passenger. It’s your job to predict these outcomes. ### Using the patterns you find in the train.csv data, predict whether the other 418 passengers on board (found in test.csv) survived. # Overview ## The data has been split into two groups: ### training set (train.csv) #### test set (test.csv) #### The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features. ##### The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic. ## About Titanic Kaggle Challenge ### Resources [Readme](https://github.com/github.com#readme-ov-file) ### Uh oh!
